previous.title: What Should My Image Look Like?

contents.content:
In this investigation you have learned how to:

  • Construct a chromatically ordered and color balanced image of a galaxy or nebula that shows where the longest and shortest wavelengths of light are coming from.
  • Look through a dusty nebula by using infrared filters
  • Find a faraway galaxy by using infrared filters
  • Locate the areas of hot young stars and star-forming regions from the blue and red light they emit in a galaxy

Now it’s your turn to answer a scientific question by creating your own color image of the cosmos and exploring what it reveals. Answer the following questions to help decide on the astronomical object, filters, and chromatic ordering for your image.

question.label: What types of objects would you like to investigate?

What question do you want to answer about your object? (choose a question from the list below or develop your own question):

  • Which is the most distant galaxy in the image?
  • Where are young stars located in a spiral galaxy?
  • Where are star forming regions located in a spiral galaxy?
  • Which stars are hidden by the dust in a nebula?
What filters are most appropriate for conducting your investigation? Why? (You don’t have to use all the filters.)
